Operation Tamarisk was a UN-led peacekeeping mission in Somalia in 1992 aimed at providing humanitarian aid and restoring order to the war-torn country. The operation faced significant challenges from the outset, including resistance from warlords and clan militias, lack of support from the local population, and inadequate resources and planning.

The situation in Somalia deteriorated rapidly, and in 1993, there was a significant escalation in violence, culminating in the Battle of Mogadishu, which was famously depicted in the movie Black Hawk Down. In the aftermath of the battle and the growing complexity of the situation, the UN Security Council made the decision to withdraw the mission from Somalia in 1995.

The failure of the mission was attributed to a combination of factors, including inadequate resources, lack of political will and support, and a misunderstanding of the local dynamics and challenges involved in the mission.

Regarding whether British soldiers faced any repercussions for their actions in Somalia, there were some incidents involving British forces that were subject to investigations and disciplinary action. For instance, there was an incident in which a British soldier shot and killed a Somali teenager during a demonstration in Mogadishu, which resulted in the soldier being court-martialed and convicted of manslaughter. However, it is unclear whether any of the specific incidents involving British forces contributed to the overall failure of the mission.
